            APT34: The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations
           
                Threat Actor
                Share Blog Post      Threat Actor ProfileOrigin: 2014Aliases: Helix Kitten, OilRig, Greenbug Key Target Sectors: Information Technology, Government, Military, Energy and Power, Communication, Transportation, Financial Services,   Educational SystemAttack Vectors:
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Zero Day Attacks, Data theft, Spam Email, Remote Code Execution, Living off the Land Attack, Social Engineering, Spearphishing, backdoor, Luring, Watering Hole AttackTarget Region:
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Western Asia, Western Europe, North America, South America, Southern Asia, South-East Asia, Africa, Eastern EuropeMalware Used: Quadagent, Twoface, Helminth, OopsIE, Karkoff, Fox Panel, HighShell, Glimpse, Webmask, RunningBee, HyperShell, ISMAgent, Poison Frog, PhpSpy, ThreeDollars, Neptun, Pickpocket, ValueVault, and Longwatch Vulnerabilities Exploited: CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2017-11882OverviewAPT34 is an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group, active since  2014.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: This group works on behalf of the Iranian government and has been observed targeting victims mostly across the Middle Eastern region.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They have targeted a variety of industries, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, and has primarily focused its operations within the Middle East.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: This adversary was originally identified and tracked as two separate groups, OilRig and APT34.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: But further research and evidence revealed an overlap between their activities, and eventually, most researchers agreed to track them as a single Threat Actor.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Most recently in mid-2019, Turla (Cyber-espionage group from Russia) hijacked the Infrastructure of this APT, in one of their attack campaigns.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Which organizations have they targeted?The group was initially observed targeting financial organizations and government agencies across the Middle Eastern region and the US, but gradually it moved to other regions and sectors.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Since 2014, the group’s attacks were focused on Middle Eastern banks and government entities since 2014.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Later, their primary targets changed, but the trend of targeting critical infrastructure and governmental entities remained the same.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In October 2016, the group was observed to be targeting government entities in Middle Eastern countries and the U.S., along with several airlines from Middle Eastern countries.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Between 2017 to 2018, the group focused more on Western-Asian and North American organizations working in Education, Information Technology and Government sector.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In April 2019, information leaked by elite hackers “Lab Dookhtegan” and “Mr_L4nnist3r” revealed the victim’s names as the Saudi Arabian Communications & Information Technology Commission, Dubai Statistics Association.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In the same duration, a small handful of targets were based outside the Middle East, including a telecom company in Zimbabwe, government bodies in Albania, and South Korean gaming business.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Most recently in June 2019, a phishing campaign was observed, targeting energy companies, government utilities, and their workers.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: What is their motivation behind the attacks?This group is known to use various malware and tools to collect strategic information that would benefit the economic and geopolitical interests of the state of Iran.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Also, Iran considers cyber-attacks as an offensive weapon against its rival countries like the United States of America and Israel.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The cyberattacks linked to the group are not that advanced or sophisticated, but highly persistent with their victim choice, which is directly or indirectly connected to Iran’s military, financial, and political interests.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Modus OperandiSince 2014, the group is known to be using Microsoft Excel macros, PowerShell-based exploits, and social engineering to gain access to its targets.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They use phishing emails to deliver weaponized Microsoft Excel documents, and most of their malware infect the target system with VisualBasic and PowerShell (.ps1) scripts.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Between 2014 to 2016, the group's attack campaigns targeted banks and technology organizations in Saudi Arabia with phishing emails that included weaponized Microsoft Excel attachments.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: One spam email had a legitimate conversation between employees, which was used as a lure, and forwarded to other employees with a weaponized attachment.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Other related campaign phishing emails used job or service offering.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In early-2017, the group was observed again, using a fake Juniper Networks VPN portal and few fake University of Oxford websites to deliver malware to the victims.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The group registered four domain names belonging to Oxford University (including oxford-careers[.]com, oxford[.]in and oxford-employee[.]com).
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In April 2017, they launched a massive cyber-espionage campaign against major Israeli institutions and government officials.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They exploited CVE-2017-0199 remote code execution vulnerability in the Windows Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) application programming interface.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They managed to target the victims before Microsoft issued a security update, and organizations rolled out the patch.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In May 2017, they expanded their geographical range with hundreds of new attacks targeting several militaries, financial and energy businesses in Europe as well as the United States.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In these attacks, they collaborated with Russian hackers-for-hire.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In Sep. 2017, an analysis done by a security firm on Two-face (web shell) disclosed a complex malicious infrastructure that was targeting Israeli institutions earlier in April.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The links between TwoFace and five other web shells were found, including RunningBee, PuTTY Link (plink) and RGDoor (for Microsoft IIS).
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In Oct. 2017, the group developed the "Agent Injector" (Trojan with the specific purpose of installing the ISMAgent backdoor) to target an organization within the United Arab Emirates government.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The attack used a spearphishing spam email that had a subject of ‘Importan Issue'.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The group was also found to be using CVE-2017-11882, an Office vulnerability patched by Microsoft on November 14, 2017.On January 8, 2018, the group launched an attack on an insurance agency based in the Middle East.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They tried to deliver a new Trojan called OopsIE, via using a variant of the ThreeDollars delivery document.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They sent two emails to two separate email addresses within the same organization.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The email address was linked with the Lebanese domain of a major global financial institution.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In Feb 2018, it was discovered that threat actor dubbed ‘Chafer’ (having an association or related to APT34) successfully compromised one of the biggest telecom firms in the Middle East using leaked NSA hacking tools.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In March 2018, the group improved their Critical Infrastructure attacks with new off-the-shelf tools, dual-purpose utilities.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They were found to be using earlier unseen malware, that uses SmartFile, Google Drive, and internet server API (ISAPI) filters for compromising Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) servers.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In July 2018, they launched multiple attacks using spearphishing email (having attached PhpSpy and QuadAgent backdoor) to target an unnamed technology services provider, the Lebanese intelligence agency, and healthcare facilities in Saudi Arabia.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Their initial infection paths were based on watering hole attacks using compromised web servers.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In Sep., they deployed a new variant of their OopsIE Trojan that came with new evasion techniques.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In the same month, they also conducted at least one attack campaign containing an updated variant of the BondUpdater Trojan (uses DNS tunneling) as its final payload.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In Nov. 2018, new information shed light on the fact that the group tests their malicious documents before they are being used in their attacks.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In April 2019, a group that calls itself Lab Dookhtegan exposed several tools (Poison Frog, Glimpse, HyperShell, HighShell, Fox Panel, and Webmask) used by this group.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In the same month, a DNSpionage malware campaign was also discovered, using a new malware called 'Karkoff.'
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The malware was delivered via an Excel document that included malicious macros.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: They also created a new remote administration tool that supported HTTP and DNS communication.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Most recently in June 2019, a Russian cyber-espionage group "Turla" was discovered to be using attack infrastructure belonging to APT34.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The infrastructure was used to deliver a backdoor called "Neptun," installed on Microsoft Exchange servers.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Also in June, a phishing campaign was observed asking victims to join their social network.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: This time the group masqueraded as a Cambridge University lecturer, also setting up a LinkedIn page in order to gain victims’ trust.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: From there they asked victims to open malicious documents.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: In this phishing campaign, three new malware families were detected, named as Pickpocket, ValueVault, and Longwatch.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Known tools and malwareThis group is known to use multiple custom malware and tools for stealing intellectual information, lateral movement, and getting an initial foothold into the targeted network.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Malicious programs used by APT34Twoface - A web shell, which is used to harvest credentialsPowruner - A backdoor known to be used by APT34.RGDoor - An Internet Information Services backdoor which is created using C++.Helminth - A Trojan that is developed to target the Windows platform.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: OopsIE -
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: A Trojan deployed and known to be used by APT34.Karkoff -
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: A malware designed to execute code remotely on compromised hosts.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: ISMAgent - A backdoor which has a sophisticated architecture and contains anti-analysis techniques.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Poison Frog - A backdoor used along with BondUpdater tool.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: PhpSpy - A backdoor used for an initial foothold in the targeted network.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Neptun - A backdoor installed on Microsoft Exchange servers as a service.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Pickpocket - It is a browser credential-theft tool.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: ValueVault - It is used to extract and view the credentials stored in the Windows Vault.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: LongWatch -  A Pickpocket variant, and browser credential-theft tool.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Custom tools used by APT34Quadagent -  A PowerShell backdoor tool, that is attributed to APT34.ThreeDollars - A delivery document, which is identified as part of the OilRig toolset.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Fox Panel - A hacking tool is known to be linked and used by APT34 HighShell - A web shell-based TwoFace payload used by APT34.Glimpse - A tool within the data dump, related to the updated BondUpdater tool.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Webmask - A series of scripts specifically meant to perform DNS hijacking.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: RunningBee - A web-based TwoFace payload used by APT34.HyperShell - A TwoFace loader known to used by APT34.Known Zero Days
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: VulnerabilitiesMicrosoft Office Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2017-0199) -
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: A remote code-execution vulnerability in Microsoft Office/Wordpad.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Microsoft Office Memory Corruption Vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) -
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: A memory-corruption vulnerability in Microsoft Office.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: AttributionThe use of infrastructure linked to Iranian operations, alignment, and timing with the national interests of Iran lead to the conclusion that this group acts or works on behalf of the Iranian government.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The persistency in the targets of their attack, which are mostly from middle-east countries, also proves the fact that the cyberattacks originated from Iran.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Most of their cyber campaigns became active when there was a holiday in Iran, and targeted specific countries with conflict of interest with Iran.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: PreventionOrganizations and security experts should review the Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) and use them with their Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) tool.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Organizations should also consider having threat intel ingestion for their existing investments in the stack of security tools like Firewalls, Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS), etc. with support for automated enrichment from external sources, which would ensure protection from latest threats across the industry.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The security experts must understand the fact that fully up-to-date antivirus (AV) or reliable antivirus software do not provide 100% protection against sophisticated attacks from threats like APT34.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: For adequate protection, they need a layered approach to their endpoint security.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Ideally, these layers must combine solutions based on dynamic security policy (e.g., behavioral-based Firewalls, Data Loss Prevention systems) as well as the control-based security policy (e.g., whitelisting, application control).
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: Enterprise networks with endpoint security solutions based on the OS-Centric security approach are more secure against the new types of APT34 attacks.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

text: The OS-centric security solutions focus on the final stage of the attack kill chain, and intended damage, so it provides better protection no matter what attack vector or method is used.
source: APT34_ The Helix Kitten Cybercriminal Group Loves to Meow Middle Eastern and International Organizations _ Blog.html

Behind the Scenes with OilRig


79,947
 people reacted

4
  24  min. read



Share 


















 







          By Bryan Lee and Robert Falcone 
April 30, 2019 at 6:00 AM
Category: Unit 42
Tags: BONDUPDATER, OilRig, OopsIE, TwoFace



 



 
This post is also available in: 
    日本語 (Japanese)After first uncovering the OilRig group in May 2016, Unit 42 has continued to monitor, observe, and track their activities and evolution over time.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Since then, OilRig has been heavily researched by the rest of the industry and has been given additional names such as APT34 and Helix Kitten.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The OilRig group is not particularly sophisticated but is extremely persistent in the pursuit of their mission objective and, unlike other some other espionage motivated adversaries, are much more willing to deviate from their existing attack methodologies and use novel techniques to accomplish their objectives.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Over time, through our research we have been able to reveal specific details of how their attacks are executed, the tools they use, and even what their development cycle may be like by tracking their use of VirusTotal as a detection check system.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Due to the nature of the data we had access to however, our perspective was primarily from a target or victim perspective which is generally limited to the artifacts at the time of attack.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Recently, a data dump was leaked and made available to the public claiming to be data in relation to OilRig activity from the operations side.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We retrieved the data dump, which included credential dumps, backdoors, webshells, and other files of interest.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Several media outlets and other researchers have since performed their own evaluation, and in our assessment, we found the artifacts contained in data dump are indeed consistent with known OilRig operations and toolsets.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In addition, the data dump allowed us to retroactively compare our previous research with OilRig’s operational data.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This allowed us to fill in previously existing gaps of OilRig’s attack life cycle in addition to validating the accuracy of our research.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: By analyzing the data dump, we have been able to identify exactly how the BONDUPDATER backdoor and its server component functions, the appearance and functionality of several webshells in deployment by OilRig, each of these tools’ internal operational names, and a better understanding of how widespread the OilRig operations may actually be from a global perspective.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The organizations possibly under attack by OilRig is widely-spread across the spectrum of industry verticals, spanning from government, media, energy, transportation and logistics, and technology service providers.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In total we identified nearly 13,000 stolen credentials, over 100 deployed webshells, and roughly a dozen backdoor sessions into compromised hosts across 27 countries, 97 organizations, and 18 industries.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
The information contained in this data dump include:

Stolen credentials
Potential systems to login to using stolen credentials
Deployed webshell URLs
Backdoor tools
Command and control server component of backdoor tools
Scripts to perform DNS hijacking
Documents identifying specific individual operators
Screenshots of OilRig operational systems

The Leak
In mid-March 2019, an unknown entity appeared on several hacking forums and Twitter with the user handle @Mr_L4nnist3r claiming they had access to data dumps involving internal tools and data used by the OilRig group.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The initial claim included several screenshots of systems potentially in use by OilRig operators for attacks, a script that appeared to be used for DNS hijacking, and a password protected archive with the filename Glimpse.rar purporting to contain the command and control server panel for an OilRig backdoor.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Soon after, a Twitter account with the user handle @dookhtegan appeared claiming they also had access to data dumps involving internal tools and data used by the OilRig group, as seen in Figure 1.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This account used an image from 2004 of a high-profile Iranian asylum seeker named Mehdy Kavousi who famously sewed his eyes and mouth shut to signify that rejecting his asylum claim and sending him back to Iran would be akin to putting him to death.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: It is unknown why this specific image was chosen, other than perhaps as a symbol of protest.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Since the initial account creation, a stylized version of the original has been substituted as the profile image, making it far more difficult to understand who the original individual was.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 1.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Tweets by @dookhtegan providing files associated with the OilRig leak
This account continued a series of tweets voicing protest against the OilRig group and attributing its operations with a specific nation state and organization.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Unit 42 is unable to validate this level of attribution, but a 2018 report from the United States National Counterintelligence and Security Center stated the OilRig group originates from an Iranian nexus.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The account continued to post tweets with direct links to operational data dumps hosted on an anonymous file sharing service.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The files posted included the previously password protected archive Glimpse.rar, as well as new archives containing hundreds of harvested credentials from compromised organizations along with details on exposed login prompts.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: There were also links to webshells previously and possibly currently deployed,  the webshell source codes, as well as another backdoor and its server component.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This account was suspended in short order, but immediately after the suspension, an alternate account with the username @dookhtegan1 with the same stylized profile image appeared and is still currently active.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This account mirrors the previous messages of exposing the OilRig group but no longer contains links to data dumps, instead instructing those that are interested in the data to join them in a private Telegram channel.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 2 shows this second Twitter account providing a Telegram channel to leak the data.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 2.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Tweets by second account @dookhtegan1 providing a Telegram channel with the leaked files
Data Dump Contents
The contents of the data dump includes various types of datasets that appear to be results from reconnaissance activity, initial compromises, and tools the OilRig operators use against target organizations.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The affected organizations spread across the spectrum of industry verticals, spanning from government, media, energy, transportation and logistics, and technology service providers.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
The datasets included:

Stolen credentials
Potential systems to login to using stolen credentials
Deployed webshell URLs
Backdoor tools
Command and control server component of backdoor tools
Script to perform DNS hijacking
Documents identifying specific individual operators
Screenshots of OilRig operational systems

We analyzed each type of dataset other than the documents containing detailed information on alleged OilRig operators and they remain consistent with previously observed OilRig tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: While we are unable to confirm the validity of the documents detailing individual operators simply due to a lack of visibility into that realm, we also have no reason to doubt their validity either.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: An interesting artifact we found in the data dump are the OilRig threat actors’ own internal names of various tools we have been tracking.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Table 1 provides the internal operational names and the names we use to track these tools.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:

Table 1.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Tools exposed in the OilRig data leak with their internal names mapped to the names used by the security community
Credential Dumps
In our analysis, we found that a total of fifteen organizations had their credentials stolen in some fashion and stored in text files for the OilRig group to then abuse for additional attacks.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In total, nearly 13,000 sets of credentials are included in the data dump.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The credentials appear to have been stolen via multiple techniques, including using post-exploition password recovery tools such as MimiKatz or its variant ZhuMimiKatz.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In addition to these tools, we believe OilRig attackers obtained credentials through, bruteforcing, SQL injections, and using traditional credential harvesting toolkits as we discussed in the Striking Oil blog published in September 2017.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: It appears to us that one organization had its entire Active Directory dumped out, making up most of the credentials we found in the data dump.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The types of organizations listed in this data dump spread across multiple industry verticals but were all largely located in the Middle East region.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We are unable to confirm if all of these stolen credentials are indeed valid sets of credentials, but based upon previously observed activity, timestamping, and known behaviors, it is highly probable that these credentials were or may still be valid.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Assuming the lists of credentials are valid, the mass collection confirms our hypothesis that the OilRig group maintains a heavy emphasis on credential based attacks along with the other types of attacks they deploy.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This is consistent with most espionage-motivated adversaries, as once the adversary gains access via legitimate credentials, they are able to masquerade as a legitimate user and essentially become an insider threat.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This type of activity becomes significantly harder to detect compared to using custom tools as the adversary masquerades as a legitimate user while most protections are intended to catch malware.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In our past research, based off artifacts we had gathered, we had internally postulated the OilRig group likely had a propensity to immediately attempt to escalate privileges once they have their initial compromise, then try to move laterally into the local Microsoft Exchange server where they would then able to harvest more credentials and implant additional tools such as webshells and IIS backdoors.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In a presentation provided by a FireEye researcher, they documented this exact attack lifecycle for incidents associated with OilRig in addition to be deploying a post-exploitation toolkit called Ruler within their attack playbook as well.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Ruler is an open-source penetration testing toolkit which is predicated on being able to access Outlook Web Access (OWA) or OWA via stolen credentials, then abusing built-in functions to perform a variety of actions including retrieving the Global Address List, setting malicious email rules, and in OilRig’s case, performing remote code execution.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The specific function of Ruler the OilRig group was using is the Ruler.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Homepage function.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This function abuses a capability in Microsoft Outlook which allows an administrator or a user to set a default homepage for any folder inside their inbox.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Using stolen credentials, the operator would use Ruler to send commands to the target organization’s OWA instance via an RPC protocol which would then remotely set an arbitrary homepage for the compromised inbox’s folders.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The operator would then include commands in the homepage to automatically retrieve and execute malicious code.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In OilRig’s case, they included commands to retrieve and execute a backdoor, immediately giving them access to the endpoint in use by the user whose credentials had been stolen.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Backdoors
The data dump included two backdoors that we had previously associated with the OilRig threat group, both of which we had previously referred to as BONDUPDATER.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Generally speaking, we are able to retrieve the implant or payload involved in an attack but are generally blind to the server side component.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This data dump provided the backdoors and their associated server components which provides us a different perspective on how the backdoors function.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In addition, we discovered that the backdoors are actually called Glimpse and Poison Frog internally by OilRig and are functionally two different tools.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Glimpse
The Glimpse tool within the data dump is related to the updated BONDUPDATER tool that we discovered being delivered to a Middle East government organization in a report we published on September 2018.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We recently mentioned this tool in another report on April 16, as this variant of the BONDUPDATER tool used DNS tunneling to communicate with its C2, specifically using TXT queries to receive information from the C2 server.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

Glimpse is a PowerShell script that contains the comment version 2.2, which suggests the OilRig group considers this a specific version of the tool and that it likely has included prior versions.

text: The Glimpse panel, versioned “v1.0.5” is the tool that the actor uses to organize the various agents installed on compromised systems.

text: The panel allows the actors to issue commands in addition to uploading files to and downloading files from the compromised endpoints.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

Poison Frog
The second backdoor included in the data dump is named Poison Frog.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The dataset includes both the agent that the actor would install on targeted systems and the server that would allow the actor to interact with compromised systems.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The Poison Frog tool appears to be a variant of BONDUPDATER used in targeted attacks in the Middle East, as reported by FireEye in December 2017.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Table 3 shows the files associated with the agent included in the data dump, of which the dUpdater.ps1 portion of Poison Frog appears to be the initial variant of BONDUPDATER that uses DNS tunneling for its C2 channel as discussed in our recent blog discussing OilRig’s DNS tunneling protocols.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Interestingly, both of these Poison Frog agent scripts were configured to use the domain myleftheart[.]com as its C2 server though we have not seen this domain in any attacks, and we were unable to associate it with any known OilRig infrastructure.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The headers included in this batch script looked very familiar, as we had seen a very similar batch script provided via the HTTP C2 channel for the Helminth backdoor delivered by a Clayslide delivery document as we reported in October 2016 (SHA256: 903b6d948c16dc92b69fe1de76cf64ab8377893770bf47c29bf91f3fd987f996).

Webshells
The data dump included several different webshells apparently used by OilRig to interact with compromised servers.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The three webshells included in the dump had names HyperShell, HighShell, and Minion, but it appears that Minion is likely a variant of HighShell based on code, filename, and functionality overlaps.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The HyperShell and HighShell webshells are variants of what we track as TwoFace, with HyperShell being related to the TwoFace loader and HighShell being related to the TwoFace payload, as we reported in July 2017.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In addition to the actual webshells in use by OilRig, the data dump includes lists of existing deployments of webshells hosted on compromised websites.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Over 100 links to webshells are listed, spanning across 87 organizations in 26 countries across four continents as seen in Figure 8.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 8.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Geographic location of webshells of impacted organizations
Hypershell
The HyperShell webshell included in the data dump (SHA256: e483eee77fcc5ef11d5bf33a4179312753b62ec9a247dd14528cc797e7632d99) is an example of the 3DES variant of the TwoFace loader that we called TwoFace++ in as we reported in July 2017.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: During our initial research into the TwoFace++ loader, we were unable to extract the embedded payload using the same brute forcing technique that we used on the initial TwoFace loader samples.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The initial TwoFace loader samples decrypted an embedded webshell using an actor provided key, which was modified by using simple arithmetic operators ("+" or "-" specifically) and a salt string embedded within the loader webshell, whose result decrypts an embedded payload using simple arithmetic operators (again, "+" or "-" specifically).
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We were able to brute force the actor-provided key using the inverse arithmetic operations using the embedded salt and embedded ciphertext, so we were able to extract the embedded webshells with ease.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Unlike the initial TwoFace loader, the TwoFace++ loader used the 3DES cipher and a SHA256 hash of a string provided by the actor and used as a key, so we were unable to extract the embedded webshells as we were unable to determine the actor provided key.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: However, the HyperShell sample in this dump provided the necessary information to determine the actor-provided key needed to decrypt its embedded webshell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Like many initial TwoFace loader samples, the HyperShell sample includes a string within the HTML tags 
 and
that is displayed in the browser if a password is not supplied and/or the TwoFace++ loader is unable to extract the embedded payload webshell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
The pre tags within the HyperShell sample are:
<pre><%= Server.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: HtmlEncode("NxKK7a") %>   Figure 9 shows HyperShell displaying the content within the "pre" tags within the browser. Figure 9.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
HyperShell displaying the password within <pre> tags
We determined the string in the pre tags is the actor provided password, which the webshell uses as a key to decrypt the embedded payload.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
We determined this by following the process in which the TwoFace++ loader webshell uses the actor provided password to authenticate and decrypt the embedded webshell:

Append a string to the password that acts as a salt
Obtain the SHA1 hash of the resulting string containing the password and salt
Base64 encode the SHA1 hash
Compare the encoded hash with hardcoded base64 string
If the encoded hash matches hardcoded base64 string then the inbound request is authenticated
Generates the SHA256 hash of the password string
Base64 encodes the SHA256 hash and uses the first 24 characters as a key
Uses 24-character key and the 3DES cipher to decrypt the embedded webshell
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Now let's look at how this works with the values in the TwoFace++ loader sample.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The actor provided password of NxKK<TjWN^lv-$*UZ|Z-H;cGL(O>7a has the hardcoded salt string aqB2nU65TgFoEfdVqiAddBQLInc9 appended to it.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The resulting string of NxKK<TjWN^lv-$*UZ|Z-H;cGL(O>7aaqB2nU65TgFoEfdVqiAddBQLInc9 has a SHA1 hash of 9d3ff106fbc3508b8453c7d6f285543d0b9c2721, which is base64 encoded to nT/xBvvDUIuEU8fW8oVUPQucJyE=. The hardcoded base64 encoded password within the sample is nT/xBvvDUIuEU8fW8oVUPQucJyE=, which confirms that the string provided in the pre tags is the password.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Once authenticated, the TwoFace++ loader uses the password to decrypt the embedded webshell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: To use the password as a key for 3DES, TwoFace++ will generate the SHA256 password of the NxKK<TjWN^lv-$*UZ|Z-H;cGL(O>7a string that results in a hash of 11f66b55f3d24303621e5ef9565b02a576cc58bc5f8789cae96c3d400064b90e.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The SHA256 hash is then base64 encoded, which results in an encoded string of EfZrVfPSQwNiHl75VlsCpXbMWLxfh4nK6Ww9QABkuQ4=, of which the first 24 characters are used as the 3DES key.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The key EfZrVfPSQwNiHl75VlsCpXbM is used as the key for 3DES, which results in a webshell (SHA256: d2b835b102117e327fdc4905ead24d45f46e82dd5ae525e90cca0a685d307619) that matches the TwoFace payload webshell we published in our original blog.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This resulting webshell also appears to be a variant of HighShell, specifically version v5.0.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We compared the v5.0 version of HighShell to the TwoFace payload (SHA256: 54c8bfa0be1d1419bf0770d49e937b284b52df212df19551576f73653a7d061f), as they are visually extremely similar.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 10 shows the two webshells sharing the same user interface, with two notable exceptions in the HighShell webshell, specifically a version number “v5.0” and three little boxes at the bottom left used to display error messages and the results of commands.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 10.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

Animation showing the differences between the HighShell v5.0 and TwoFace payload
To supplement the visual similarities, we performed an analysis of the code of the two webshells to identify overlaps.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The most notable difference is that the HighShell v5.0 webshell includes a salt value it applies to the actor provided password that it uses for authentication.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 11 shows the code comparison between the TwoFace payload on the left (SHA256: 54c8bfa0be1d1419bf0770d49e937b284b52df212df19551576f73653a7d061f) and HighShell v5.0 on the right (SHA256: d2b835b102117e327fdc4905ead24d45f46e82dd5ae525e90cca0a685d307619).

Spy Check
The Spy Check functionality appears at the top right corner of the webshell as a box with a countdown timer.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The timer starts at 300 and decrements every second, suggesting that the webshell executes the Spy Check functionality every five minutes.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The Spy Check functionality is rather interesting, as we do not know its exact purpose other than either displaying a red box with a spy icon or a green box with a heart icon.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We believe this functionality was meant to notify the actor in the event that they were using an altered HighShell front end webshell, possibly to avoid using the webshell if it had been detected and modified by a third-party.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: We are speculating this is the intended function because the Spy Check function begins by reading the .aspx file of the HighShell front end (HighShellLocal.aspx in this case).
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The Spy Check then generates the SHA256 hash of the HighShell front end and compares it with a hardcoded SHA256 of f35e566e28be5b3257670be6e125eb90814b9cb27df997090cea0b7a22fbd75c to determine if the webshell had been modified.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: If the hashes do not match, the webshell will display a red box with spy icon, as seen in Figure 15, or a green box with a heart icon if it matches.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: All known samples display the red box with a spy icon, suggesting that the developer of HighShell did not update this functionality during development efforts or that the samples have been modified in some way.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Network Downloader
The Network Downloader functionality allows the actor to quickly upload user files from remote victim systems.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: To use this functionality, the actor must provide information within the "Target Computer" portion of the webshell, specifically a network administrator username and password, as well as a list of IP addresses of remote systems added in the "Select Computer" drop down.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Before performing the network download, the webshell checks the storage volume on the server that the webshell is running on to determine if it has more than 30 GB of free space.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: If the server has less than 30 GB of free space the webshell will not perform the activity, which indicates that the developer of the webshell expects a high volume of data downloaded from the victim network.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
The webshell will iterate through the IP list and perform a series of commands for each IP, starting off with using the following command to connect to the remote system:
net use [IP address] /user:[domain admin username]
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
[domain admin password] 2>&1
After connecting to the remote system with net use, the webshell will run the following command to obtain a list of user folders:
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: dir /b
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
[IP address]\c$\Users 2>&1
With a list of user folders, the webshell will iterate through the list of users and enumerate all of the files in the following folders:
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
[IP address]\c$\Users\[username]\Desktop
[IP address]\c$\Users\[username]\Documents
[IP address]\c$\Users\[username]\Downloads
The Network Downloader function will gather all the files in these folders and use 7-Zip to compress and archive the files.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The webshell will save the archives locally to the server in the C:\Users\Public\Libraries\Recorded\Files folder, each with a filename with the following structure:
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
[IP address]_c$_Users_[username]__[Desktop-Documents-Downloads]_[year]-[month]-[day]-[hours]-[minutes]-[seconds].7z
It is likely that the threat actors use this functionality to rapidly check for new files created by users on the network.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Minion
Minion appears to be another webshell related to HighShell, as it contains similar functionality and significant code overlap.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Based on the login functionality within Minion, we believe the same entities were involved in the development of Minion and HyperShell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: To use Minion, the actor must provide the username of admin and a password to authenticate before using the webshell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: To authenticate, the password has the string O%tG7Hz57kvWk35$D*)s$1l$pUpLnBw)apHR!xYZWZu7X#^w7$mCArmQMAa&sRBG appended to it as a salt value.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The webshell generates the SHA256 hash of the resulting string and base64 encodes it to compare with the hardcoded string of m6m8CCWa/u820mie8bX3HKIx1+WQkB+lbmniyXWKB+8=.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The password and salt string must result in a SHA256 hash of 9ba9bc08259afeef36d2689ef1b5f71ca231d7e590901fa56e69e2c9758a07ef to properly authenticate.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This is the exact same process used to authenticate/decrypt within HyperShell.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Much like HighShell version 8.6.2, Minion includes modules to extend the webshell’s functionality.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Table 6 shows the modules included with Minion, three of which are the same exact files as seen in the HighShell and Minion including Hobocopy and a port scanning, screenshot tool called Tardigrade.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Filename
SHA256
Description


7za.exe
dd6d7af00ef4ca89a319a230cdd094275c3a1d365807fe5b34133324bdaa0229
7-Zip 17.01 beta


hb.exe
3ca3a957c526eaeabcf17b0b2cd345c0fffab549adfdf04470b6983b87f7ec62
Hobocopy

c9d5dc956841e000bfd8762e2f0b48b66c79b79500e894b4efa7fb9ba17e4e9e

a6a0fbfee08367046d3d26fb4b4cf7779f7fb6eaf7e60e1d9b6bf31c5be5b63e

fe1b011fe089969d960d2dce2a61020725a02e15dbc812ee6b6ecc6a98875392

source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Can perform port scanning, screenshots and connect to remote systems with “net use”.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Table 6.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Modules included with the Minion webshell
DNS Hijacking Script
In November 2018, Cisco Talos published research on an attack campaign named DNSpionage.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: It involved attacks using malware to compromise individual endpoints, but most interestingly described an effort to specifically hijack DNS entries of government organizations to redirect visitors to likely malicious, adversary operated systems.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Both FireEye and Crowdstrike followed up with their own assessments for the DNS hijacking efforts, and described operations extending back to January 2017.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: No attribution to any known adversary groups was provided, other than that the target radius was primarily in the Middle East and the adversary was also likely operating out of that region.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In this data dump, a tool called webmask is included which appears to be a series of scripts specifically meant to perform DNS hijacking.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: An informational document is included titled guide.txt, as seen in Figure 16 that provides instructions to the operator on how to execute the DNS hijacking attack using the provided tools.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Based upon the instructional guide and the provided tools, this package appears consistent with the methodologies FireEye outlined in their research on how these attacks were executed, including specific details such as the use of ICAP via a proxy passthrough, in this case specifically squid, and using certbot to create a Let’s Encrypt SSL certificate.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 16.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Instructions within guide.txt explaining how to carry out DNS hijacking attack
In one part of guide.txt, an example target appears to be provided, with a corresponding adversary IP (185.162.235[.]106) for the legitimate domain to be redirected to.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Analysis of this IP provides several interesting data points, including possible relationships to previously observed OilRig infrastructure.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Examining the hosting provider shows that the IP is associated with an Iranian hosting provider called NovinVPS.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The autonomous system name of the IP shows that the allocation is controlled by Serverius Holding B.V., which is an autonomous system name we have previously seen associated with the OilRig group.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In fact, examining the Class C IP block of 185.162.235[.]0/24 shows at least two other IPs we have previously identified as in use by the OilRig group for C2 servers.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: 185.162.235[.]29 and 185.162.235[.]121 and their associated domains, office365-management[.]com and msoffice-cdn[.]com respectively.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Office365-management[.]com was first identified in October 2017 as a C2 servers for OilRig operations delivering the ISMInjector backdoor.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Later in February 2018 we were able to link the entire grouping of infrastructure to another campaign delivering the OopsIE backdoor via the reuse of WHOIS registrant artifacts, shared SSL certificates, and a shared Class C IP block.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 17 shows the relationship between the files related to DNS hijacking and known infrastructure associated with OilRig.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 17.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Relationship between DNS Hijacking files and OilRig infrastructure
Although we are unable to say with certainty that the DNSpionage operations were absolutely executed by the OilRig group, it is possible based on the provided data that there may be some level of relationship between them.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Screenshots
The data dump includes several screenshots of resources that the leaker alleged was related to the OilRig group.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The screenshots included remote desktop (RDP) sessions showing the Glimpse panel, a web browser session displaying a C2 panel called Scarecrow, web browser sessions into VPS administrative panels, and evidence of potential destructive attacks against OilRig servers.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The screenshot in Figure 18. appears to be a C2 panel for an unknown backdoor.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The only name provided is Scarecrow, which is not a name we have previously observed or associated with OilRig.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The server is hosted on 142.234.157[.]21 which appears to be hosted by LeaseWeb.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: If we are to assume the filename is consistent with a real time snapshot of the server panel, it would indicate that multiple systems were actively compromised as of March 29, 2019.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 18.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Screenshot provided in leak showing Scarecrow panel
Figure 19 shows an administrative panel to an Iranian based virtual hosting provider called Berbid Server.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: No other infrastructure details are displayed.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 19.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Screenshot provided in leak showing administrative panel for hosting provider Berbid Server
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The screenshot showed the administrative panel for a VPS account on DeltaHost with four different virtual servers, as seen in Figure 20.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: One of these virtual servers was hosted at an IP address of 193.111.152[.]13 and had been up for 194 days (in the red box in Figure 20) at the time this control panel was apparently accessed.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 20.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Screenshot in leak of administrative panel for an account at DeltaHost
If we use the filename of this screenshot and assume that it was taken on March 29, 2019 and subtract 194 days from this date, it is possible that this server had been operational since at least September 16, 2018.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
On September 24, 2018, we observed an organization targeted by OilRig attempting to download a Zip archive from the following URL:
hxxp://193.111.152[.]13/[redacted]-ITsoftwareUpdate.zip
This Zip archive contained a file named [redacted]-ITsoftwareUpdate.exe (SHA256: 5f42deb792d8d6f347c58ddbf634a673b3e870ed9977fdd88760e38088cd7336), which is a variant of the OopsIE Trojan we described in detail in a blog we published in September 2018.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This suggests that the server displayed in the VPS control panel may have indeed been in use by the OilRig threat actors at the time of attack.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: In addition, two of the other IPs listed in this panel, 185.161.209[.]57 and 185.161.210[.]25 are in the same 185.161.208[.]0/22 range as an IP associated with the DNSpionage campaign, 185.161.211[.]72.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This is a tenuous relationship at best and does not indicate that the OilRig group is the one executing the DNSpionage campaign, but with the combination of the use of DeltaHost and IPs belonging to a fairly small range, there may be reason to believe that these are related to some extent.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 21 is a screenshot of a C2 server panel for Glimpse, which we track using the name BONDUPDATER.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: This screenshot is via an RDP session as indicated by the tab located at the top of the screen and is located at 164.132.67[.]216 which is hosted by OVH.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: If we again assume the accuracy of the time indicated in the filename, this would indicate that no compromised system had checked in since as far out as 71 days.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Figure 21.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text:
Screenshot in leak of RDP session with a server running the Glimpse C2 
Conclusion
This data dump has provided a rare and unusual perspective into the behind-the-scenes activity in an adversary’s operations.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: It is important to understand that although we are able to validate the backdoors and webshells provided in the dataset as consistent with previously researched OilRig toolsets, in general we are unable to validate the origins of the entirety of the dataset and cannot confirm nor deny that the data has not been manipulated in some manner.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: It is certainly possible that the data dump did indeed originate from a whistleblower, but it is just as likely that a third party was able to extract this data.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Looking at the data dump as a whole though, the targeting and TTPs are consistent with behaviors we have generally associated with OilRig in the past.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: Assuming the data in the dump is accurate, it also shows the global reach of the OilRig threat group, which generally is assumed to operate primarily in the Middle East.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

text: The disparity in regions and industries for organizations potentially affected or compromised by OilRig is an excellent example of why organizations regardless of region or industry should always maintain situational awareness of adversaries, their activities, and be prepared to defend against any attack.
source: Behind the Scenes with OilRig.html

    Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram
   
    APT34 hacking tools and victim data leaked on a secretive Telegram channel since last month.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text:
Written by 
            Catalin Cimpanu, Contributor   April 17, 2019 at 4:24 p.m. PT                 must read   Have 10 hours?
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text:

      In an incident reminiscent of the Shadow Brokers leak that exposed the NSA's hacking tools, someone has now published similar hacking tools belonging to one of Iran's elite cyber-espionage units, known as APT34, Oilrig, or HelixKitten.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The hacking tools are nowhere near as sophisticated as the NSA tools leaked in 2017, but they are dangerous nevertheless.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Victim data also dumped onlineThe tools have been leaked since mid-March on a Telegram channel by an individual using the Lab Dookhtegan pseudonym.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Besides hacking tools, Dookhtegan also published what appears to be data from some of APT34's hacked victims, mostly comprising of username and password combos that appear to have been collected through phishing pages.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: ZDNet was previously aware of some of these tools and victim data after this reporter received a tip in mid-March.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In a Twitter DM, a Twitter user shared some of the same files that were discovered today on Telegram, and we believe that this Twitter user is the Telegram Lab Dookhtegan persona.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Image: ZDNetIn our Twitter conversation, the leaker claimed to have worked on the group's DNSpionage campaign, but this should be taken with a grain of salt, as the leaker could very well be a member of a foreign intelligence agency trying to hide their real identity while giving more credence to the authenticity of Iran's hacking tools and operations.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Furthermore, ZDNet has also learned that the same Twitter persona had also contacted tens of other reporters and infosec researchers with the same message, in an attempt to promote the leak.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Similarly, the same persona has also posted links to some of these hacking tools on public hacking-focused forums.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: On these forums, he claimed to be selling the hacked files, yet, he never mentioned anything about a price.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Authenticity confirmedSeveral cyber-security experts have already confirmed the authenticity of these tools.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Chronicle, Alphabet's cyber-security division, confirmed this to ZDNet earlier today.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In the Telegram channel discovered today, the hacker leaked  the source code of six hacking tools, and the content from several active backend panels, where victim data had been collected.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Hacking tools:- Glimpse (newer version of a PowerShell-based trojan that Palo Alto Networks names BondUpdater)- PoisonFrog (older version of BondUpdater)- HyperShell (web shell that Palo Alto Networks calls TwoFace)- HighShell (another web shell)- Fox Panel (phishing kit)- Webmask (DNS tunneling, main tool behind DNSpionage)Besides source code for the above tools, Dookhtegan also leaked on the Telegram channel data taken from victims that had been collected in some of APT34's backend command-and-control (C&C) servers.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Image: ZDNetIn total, according to Chronicle, Dookhtegan leaked data from 66 victims, mainly from countries in the Middle East, but also Africa, East Asia, and Europe.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Data was taken from both government agencies, but also from private companies.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The two biggest companies named on the Telegram channel are Etihad Airways and Emirates National Oil.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: A list of the victims (but without company/government agency names) is available here.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Data leaked from each victim varied, ranging from usernames and password combos to internal network servers info and user IPs.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Additionally, Dookhtegan also leaked data about past APT34 operations, listing the IP addresses and domains where the group had hosted web shells in the past, and other operational data.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Image: ZDNetBesides data on past operations, the leaker also doxxed Iranian Ministry of Intelligence officers, posting phone numbers, images, and names of officers involved with APT34 operations.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: For some officers, Dookhtegan created PDF files containing their names, roles, images, phone numbers, email addresses, and social media profiles.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Image: ZDNetIt was clear from the detailed doxing packages that the leaker had a bone to pick with the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence officers, to which he referred many times as "cruel," "ruthless," and "criminal.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: ""We have more secret information about the crimes of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and its managers and we are determined to continue to expose them," Dookhtegan said in a Telegram message posted last week.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The leaker also posted screenshots on the Telegram channel alluding to destroying the control panels of APT34 hacking tools and wiping servers clean.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Image: ZDNet      Image:
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: ZDNetThe data leaked on this Telegram channel is now under analysis by several cyber-security firms, ZDNet was told.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: It has also made its way on other file sharing sites, such as GitHub.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: "It's likely this group will alter their toolset in order to maintain operational status," Brandon Levene, Head of Applied Intelligence at Chronicle, told ZDNet today in an email "There may be some copycat activity derived from the leaked tools, but it is unlikely to see widespread use.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: "This is because the tools aren't sophisticated and aren't top-tier tools like the ones leaked in the Shadow Brokers' NSA leak.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Nation-state or criminal groups who will reuse these tools will most likely do it as a smoke-screen or false flag, to mask their operations as APT34.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html
