APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor 
Posted: May 10, 2022
 by Threat Intelligence Team 


On April 26th, we identified a suspicious email that targeted a government official from Jordan’s foreign ministry.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The email contained a malicious Excel document that drops a new backdoor named Saitama.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Following our investigation, we were able to attribute this attack to the known Iranian Actor APT34.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Also known as OilRig/COBALT GYPSY/IRN2/HELIX KITTEN, APT34 is an Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern countries and victims worldwide since at least 2014.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The group is known to focus on the financial, governmental, energy, chemical, and telecommunication sectors.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In this blog post, we describe the attack flow and share details about the Saitama backdoor.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Malicious email file The malicious email was sent to the victim via a Microsoft Outlook account with the subject “Confirmation Receive Document” with an Excel file called “Confirmation Receive Document.xls”.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The sender pretends to be a person from the Government of Jordan by using its coat of arms as a signature.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Excel document The Excel attachment contains a macro that performs malicious activities.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The document has an image that tries to convince the victim to enable a macro.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: After enabling the macro, the image is replaced with the Jordan government’s the coat of the arms:
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The macro has been executed on WorkBook_Open().
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Here are the main functionalities of this macro:   Hides the current sheet and shows the new sheet that contains the coat of arms image.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Calls the “eNotif’ function which is used to send a notification of each steps of macro execution to its server using the DNS protocol.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: To send a notification it builds the server domain for that step that contains the following parts: “qw” + identification of the step (in this step “zbabz”)
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: + random number + domain name (joexpediagroup.com)=qwzbabz7055.joexpediagroup.com.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Then it uses the following WMI query to get the IP address of the request: Select *
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: From Win32_PingStatus Where Address='” & p_sHostName & “‘” which performs the DNS communication the the created subdomain.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Creates a TaskService object and Gets the task folder that contains the list of the current tasks Calls ENotif function Checks if there is a mouse connected to PC and if that is the case performs the following steps  Creates %APPDATA%/MicrosoftUpdatedirectory Creates “Update.exe”, “Update.exe.config” and “Microsoft.Exchange.WenServices.dll” Reads the content of the UserForm1.label1, UserForm2.label1 and UserForm3.label1 that are in base64 format, decodes them and finally writes them into the created files in the previous step Calls a ENotif function for each writes function   Checks the existence of theUpdate.exefile and if for some reason it has not been written to disk, it writes it using a technique that loads a DotNet assembly directly using mscorlib and Assembly.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Load by manually accessing the VTable of the IUnknown.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This technique was taken from Github (link).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Even though, this technique was not used in this macro since the file was already written, the function name (“Test”) suggests that the threat actor is trying to implement this technique in future attacks.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Finally, it calls the ENotif function.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Defines a xml schema for a scheduled task and registers it using the RegisterTask function.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The name of the scheduled task is MicrosoftUpdate and is used to make update.exepersistent.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Saitama Backdoor – A finite state machine The dropped payload is a small backdoor that is written in .Net.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It has the following interesting pdb path: E:SaitamaSaitama.AgentobjReleaseSaitama.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Agent.pdb.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Saitama backdoor abuses the DNS protocol for its command and control communications.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This is stealthier than other communication methods, such as HTTP.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Also, the actor cleverly uses techniques such as compression and long random sleep times.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: They employed these tricks to disguise malicious traffic in between legitimate traffic.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Another element that we found interesting about this backdoor is the way that it is implemented.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The whole flow of the program is defined explicitly as a finite-state machine, as shown in the Figure 7.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In short, the machine will change its state depending on the command sent to every state.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Graphically, the program flow can be seen as this:  The finite-machine state can be: BEGIN It is the initial state of the machine.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It just accepts the start command that puts the machine into the ALIVE state.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: ALIVE This state fetches the C&C server, expecting to receive a command from the attackers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These servers are generated by using the PRNG algorithm that involves transformations like the Mersenne Twister.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These transformations will generate subdomains of the hard coded domains in the Config class (Figure 8).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Figure 9 shows an example of the generated subdomain:
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This state has two possible next stages.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: If the performed DNS request fails, the next stage is SLEEP.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Otherwise, the next stage is RECEIVE.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: SLEEP and SECOND SLEEP These states put the backdoor in sleep mode.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The amount of time that the program will sleep is determined by the previous stage.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It is clear that one of the main motivations of the actor is to be as stealthy as possible.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: For example, unsuccessful DNS requests puts the backdoor in sleep mode for a time between 6 and 8 hours!
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: There are different sleep times depending on the situations (values are expressed in milliseconds):  There is also a “Second Sleep” state that puts the program on sleep mode a different amount of time.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: RECEIVE This state is used to receiving commands from the C&C servers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Commands are sent using the IP address field that is returned by the DNS requests.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Further details about the communication protocol are provided later in this report.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In a nutshell, every DNS request is capable of receiving 4 bytes.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The backdoor will concatenate responses, building buffers in that way.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These buffers will contain the commands that the backdoor will execute.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: DO (DoTask) That state will execute commands received from the server.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The backdoor has capabilities like executing remote pre-established commands, custom commands or dropping files.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The communication supports compression, also.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The following figure shows the list of possible commands that can be executed by the backdoor.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: ID Type Command     1 PS Get-NetIPAddress -AddressFamily IPv4 | Select-Object IPAddress   2 PS Get-NetNeighbor -AddressFamily
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: IPv4 | Select-Object “IPADDress”   3 CMD whoami   4 PS [System.Environment]::OSVersion.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: VersionString   5 CMD net user   6 — ———[NOT USED]———   7 PS Get-ChildItem -Path “C:Program Files” | Select-Object Name   8 PS Get-ChildItem -Path ‘C:Program Files (x86)’
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: | Select-Object Name   9 PS Get-ChildItem -Path ‘C:’
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: | Select-Object Name   10 CMD hostname   11 PS Get-NetTCPConnection | Where-Object{$_.State -eq “Established”} | Select-Object “LocalAddress”, “LocalPort”, “RemoteAddress”, “RemotePort”   12 PS $(ping -n 1 10.65.4.50 | findstr /i ttl)

text: “Domain”    Figure 12: List of predefined commands
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It is pretty shocking to see that even when attackers have the possibility of sending any command, they choose to add that predefined list in the backdoor in Base64 format.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As we can see, some of them are common reconnaissance snippets, but some of them are not that common.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In fact, some of the commands contain internal IPsand also internal domain names(like ise-posture.mofagov.gover.local).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: That shows that this malware was clearly targeted and also indicates that the actor has some previous knowledge about the internal infrastructure of the victim.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: SEND – SEND AND RECEIVE The Send state is used to send the results generated by commands to the actor’s server.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In this case, the name of the subdomain will contain the data.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As domain names are used to exfiltrate unknown amounts of data, attackers had to split this data in different buffers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Every buffer is then sent through a different DNS request.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As it can be seen in the Figure 12, all the required information in order to reconstruct original data is sent to the attackers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The size of the buffer is only sent in the first packet.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Attribution There are several indicators that suggest that this campaign has been operated by APT34.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Maldoc similarity: The madoc used in this campaign shared some similarities with maldocs used in previous campaigns of this actor.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: More specifically similar to what was mentioned in CheckPoint’s
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: reportthis maldoc registers a scheduled task that would launch the executable every X minutes, also it uses the same anti sandboxing technique (checking if there is a mouse connected to the PC or not).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Finally, we see a similar pattern to beacon back to the attacker server and inform the attacker about the current stage of execution.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Victims similarity: The group is known to target the government of Jordan and this is the case in this campaign.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Payload similarity: DNS is the most common method used byAPT34 for its C&C communications.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The group is also known to use uncommon encodings such as Base32 and Base36 in its previous campaigns.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The Saitama backdoor uses a similar Base32 encoding for sending data to the servers that is used by DNSpionage.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Also, to build subdomains it uses Base32 encoding that is similar to what was reported by Mandiant.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal

									
									April 8, 2021								





 
 


https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/irans-apt34-returns-with-an-updated-arsenal/


 


Introduction

Check Point Research discovered evidence of a new campaign by the Iranian threat group APT34 (aka OilRig), against what appears to be a Lebanese target, employing a new backdoor variant we dubbed SideTwist.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Since the 2019 leak of APT34’s tools by an entity named “Lab Dookhtegan”, the threat group has been actively retooling and updating their payload arsenal to try and avoid detection, creating several different malware variants whose ultimate purpose remained the same: to gain the initial foothold on the targeted device.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Starting with the DNSpionage campaign back in 2018, APT34 has been observed targeting individuals through the use of booby-trapped job opportunity documents, delivered directly to the selected targets via LinkedIn messages.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This activity continued through 2019 with the HardPass operation, in which the LinkedIn platform was used in the same manner.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this latest campaign from January, a document submitted to VirusTotal from Lebanon (a common target for APT34), also depicts such a job opportunity document, although in this case we were unable to confirm the initial delivery mechanism to the target.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In the following article we analyze the latest infection chain used by the attackers and deep dive into the new malware variant.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Initial Infection
Our analysis began with a malicious Microsoft Word document named Job-Details.doc (md5: 6615c410b8d7411ed14946635947325e).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Fig 1: Lure document with malicious macros


The decoy document clearly tries to appear like a benign document, offering various positions in the Ntiva IT consulting company – a company based in Virginia, US.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: However, once the user activates the embedded malicious macros, the full infection flow is triggered:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Fig 2: Infection Flow


Malicious Macros with DNS tunneling
Macros used by APT34’s job opportunity campaigns have evolved through the years, but also managed to keep their own distinctive style and purpose:

Verification that there is a mouse connected to the PC (Anti-Sandboxing technique).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Initial fingerprinting of the target device and sending of the information to the C2 server.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Dropping embedded executable to disk with a “doc” extension (later to be renamed to “.exe”).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Registering a Windows schedule task that would launch the executable every X minutes.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Fig 3: VBA functions call graph generated by Vba2Graph


In the macros function call graph above, we can see that from the Document_Open and the Document_Close functions, there are multiple calls to the DnsQuery external function.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: APT34 is notorious for its heavy use of DNS tunneling through many of their different tools, and this time this feature also made its way into the initial macros stage.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Once the macros are executed, DNS requests are used to beacon back to the attacker, and inform them of the current stage of the execution, as well as to deliver some victim identifiable information.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Fig 4: Snippet from the malicious macros, responsible for sending DNS queries


In this step, the attacker is using the publicly available requestbin.net DNS tunneling service, in order to get updates about the macros infection progress.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This way the attacker-owned infrastructure would not be exposed, in case a sandbox would not be able to fully “detonate” the document.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Below is a demonstration of the information the attacker would see on the requesbin.net website, when a victim executes the malicious macros from a system with the following environment:

User name: John
Hostname: John-pc



Fig 5: The macro requests as viewed on “requesbin.net”, with source IP address and timestamp redacted


The encoded data is derived from the PC information, in the following manner:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Fig 6: encoded DNS data


Second Stage Payload:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
SideTwist
The backdoor in this stage, is a variant we haven’t seen before in previous APT34 operations, but provides functionality which is simple and similar to other C based backdoors utilized by the group: DNSpionage and TONEDEAF and TONEDEAF2.0.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The functionality of the backdoor includes download, upload and shell command execution.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Persistence
In this infection chain the persistence is actually established by the 1st stage macros, and the 2nd stage payload does not have any persistence mechanism of its own.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Persistence is achieved in the 1st stage, when the schedule task is registered.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The scheduled task named SystemFailureReporter will execute the 2nd stage payload every 5 minutes:


Fig 7: Scheduled task on an infected machine


The backdoor is very dependent on this persistence mechanism, as every time it would launch, it would only execute a single command provided from the C&C server and immediately shut down, until it is launched again by the scheduled task.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Initialization
The backdoor starts by collecting basic information about the victim’s machine and calculating a 4-byte long victim identifier, based on the user-name, computer-name and the domain name of the target environment.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This identifier will be used in the follow-up C&C communication.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Fig 8: Code to gather identifiable information
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Next the malware will verify that the update.xml file that was supposed to be created in the 1st stage of the infection does indeed exists, and if not, it will terminate itself – printing the following text to the debugging output using the OutputDebugString function:
“Please install visual studio 2017 and try again”


Fig 9: Code to verify that the 1st stage was executed


As the purpose of this function is to print debugging information, only during the debugging process of an application, the text will not be visible to the regular user.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
C&C communication
The backdoor’s communication with the C&C server (sarmsoftware[.]com) is HTTP based on port 443 with port 80 as fallback.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The backdoor uses two different techniques for its outgoing and incoming communications with the C&C server, though in both cases the same encryption algorithm is utilized (see more on encryption below).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html
Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The response to this request is hidden in the source code of following Flickr lookalike page:


Fig 10: Fake Flickr lookalike page used as C&C
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The response is returned to the backdoor within the HTML code, in the following format:
/*Encrypted_Message_Encoded_with_Base64*/


Fig 11: C&C commands embedded within the code


After this base64 string is decoded and decrypted, the plain-text content is in the following pipe-separated format:


Fig 12: Encrypted data format



Command Number – a running index number to keep track of executed commands.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: If set to any number other than -1, the backdoor should proceed to execute the command, according to the Command ID.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Otherwise, ignore and terminate.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Command ID – can be one of the following commands:

101 – Shell Command: execute the Shell command attached in the {Arg1} argument.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
102 – Download File: Downloads a file that can be found on the {Arg2} path on the server, and saves it on the disk with the {Arg1} name.


103 – Upload File: Uploads a local file {Arg1} to the server.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: 104 – Shell Command (duplicate): execute the Shell command attached in the {Arg1} argument.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Command Results Communication
After the backdoor has executed an arbitrary command on the victim’s machine, it returns the result of the executed command to the C&C server, to the same URL as before, but in a POST request instead of a GET:
sarmsoftware[.]com/search/{identifier}
The format of the POST body is a simple JSON, based on the command number provided from the C&C server and the encrypted result of the command execution:


Fig 13: Result data format


Communication Encryption
As the basis for the encrypted communication, the attackers utilize the Mersenne Twister pseudorandom number generator.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The 4 first bytes of each encrypted message is the seed for the Mersenne Twister, to be used for the decryption of the rest of the message.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The encrypted Base64 communication can be decrypted using the following Python snippet:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Plain textCopy to clipboardOpen code in new windowEnlighterJS 3 Syntax Highlighterdef decode(msg):    bs=base64.b64decode(msg)    seed=int.from_bytes(bs[:4],byteorder='big')
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
rng = mersenne_rng(seed)    k=rng.get_random_number()    key=int.to_bytes(k,length=4,byteorder='little')    dec="".join([chr(bs[i]^key[(i-4)%4]) for i in range(4,len(bs))]) return decdef decode(msg):
    bs=base64.b64decode(msg)
    seed=int.from_bytes(bs[:4],byteorder='big')
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
rng = mersenne_rng(seed)
    k=rng.get_random_number()
    key=int.to_bytes(k,length=4,byteorder='little')
    dec="".join([chr(bs[i]^key[(i-4)%4]) for i in range(4,len(bs))])
    return decdef decode(msg):
    bs=base64.b64decode(msg)
    seed=int.from_bytes(bs[:4],byteorder='big')
    rng = mersenne_rng(seed)
    k=rng.get_random_number()
    key=int.to_bytes(k,length=4,byteorder='little')
    dec="".join([chr(bs[i]^key[(i-4)%4]) for i in range(4,len(bs))])
    return dec
Attribution
Both the malicious macros, the backdoor, the targeting, and the techniques used in this operation – all align with previously reported campaigns attributed to APT34.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Document Similarity
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Besides the fact that like in previous APT34 operations, once again we see job opportunity documents being used to encourage the victim to enable macros, there are technical similarities as well.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The same variable name beacher was present in and old DNSpionage campaign:



Fig 14: Similar variable name in old macros code



The main functionality of the macros remained the same as in a previous APT34 campaign: The malicious macros use the MouseAvailable function for evasion, and create a scheduled task to execute a payload embedded within the document.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
C&C Communication Similarity
APT34’s backdoors DNSpionage and TONEDEAF are known to receive commands from the servers by searching for specific pattern hidden inside the HTML content of a legitimate looking website.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In our case the attackers utilized a Flickr lookalike page, while in previous campaigns GitHub, Wikipedia, and Microsoft lookalikes were used.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Additional APT34 Sightings
While analyzing the above campaign, this and additional APT34 related documents were uploaded to VirusTotal and noted by malware researchers on Twitter.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: These documents utilized the very same requestbin.net DNS tunneling service in the initial macros and delivered another of the group’s signature tools: a variant of the .NET based backdoor named Karkoff, which utilized internet facing exchange servers as a communication method with the attackers.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The newly found artifacts emphasize the extent of the ongoing APT34’s offensive operations against targets in the Middle East, and especially in Lebanon:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The Karkoff implant (MD5: ab25014c3d6f77ec5880c8f9728be968) included credentials for an exchange server belonging to the Lebanese Government (mail.army.gov[.]lb), which might be an indication of a long running compromise of their network.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Conclusion
Iran backed APT34 shows no sign of slowing down, further pushing its political agenda in the middle-east, with an ongoing focus on Lebanon – using offensive cyber operations.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: While maintaining its modus operandi and reusing old techniques, as reviewed above, the group continues to create new and updated tools to minimize the possible detection of their tools by security vendors.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this publication we analyzed the newest backdoor variant deployed by the group’s ongoing job opportunities campaigns, which includes malicious documents with job offers – a technique they have successfully employed since at least 2018.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Check Point Sandblast protects against this APT attack, and prevents it from the very first steps.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

Threat Brief: Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations


42,241
 people reacted

44
  6  min. read



Share 


















 







          By Unit 42 
January 9, 2020 at 6:00 PM
Category: Threat Brief, Unit 42
Tags: APT, APT34, Cobalt Gypsy, DarkHydrus, Elfin, Helix Kitten, magic hound, MuddyWater, Newscaster, OilRig, Refined Kitten, Shamoon, Shamoon 2, Shamoon 3, Static Kitten, threat brief



 



 
This post is also available in: 
    日本語 (Japanese)Executive Summary
With elevated tensions in the Middle East region, there is significant attention being paid to the potential for cyber attacks emanating from Iran.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The following threat brief contains a summary of historical campaigns that are associated with Iranian activity and does not expose any new threat or attack that has occurred since the events of January 3rd, 2020.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Since 2010, it is thought that Iran has been highly active in cyber operations campaigns throughout the world.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: A number of groups and campaigns have been named and published on by the private sector, but direct attribution to the nation-state of Iran is still largely lacking in many of these instances.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Most attribution published by the private sector has relied on tactical evidence surrounding targeting and possible motivations.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: It is important to keep this in mind, while at the same time understanding that without additional evidence, the current attribution set is accepted industry-wide as fact.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Unit 42 has not gathered evidence to specifically attribute any of the accepted groups as originating from Iran, but also has not observed any evidence to counter any publicly made claims.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
Overview of Iran-Linked Campaigns: Some of the currently active groups or campaigns publicly attributed by the industry as originating from Iran are:

OilRig (AKA APT34/Helix Kitten)
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
MagicHound (AKA APT35/Newscaster/Cobalt Gypsy)
APT33 (AKA Refined Kitten/Elfin)
DarkHydrus
Shamoon
MuddyWater (AKA Static Kitten)

There appear to be two distinct motivators for these groups, espionage and destruction.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The majority of observed attack campaigns have been espionage related, with the associated groups appearing to seek continued access into a target organization or access to sensitive data.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: A smaller number of highly focused destructive attacks have been observed over time, beginning with the original Shamoon attack in 2012, with additional iterations years after, and more recently with StoneDrill and ZeroCleare.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Overall, cyber attacks thought to be originating from Iran have been persistent and ongoing for the last decade.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The target radius for these groups have spanned across the globe, across all major industries.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Although perceived retaliatory actions may occur in the near future, even those actions are most likely in conjunction with ongoing attack campaigns and operations.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Iranian TTPs: Behaviorally, several tactics and techniques have been observed across multiple groups and campaigns over time.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The following is a list of commonly observed tactics and techniques along with their associated ATT&CK IDs:
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
Phishing (T1193 and T1192)
Credential harvesting (T1078, T1003, T1503, T1081, T1214)
DNS Tunneling (T1071)
DNS Hijacking (T1326)
EldoS RawDisk driver (T1485, T1488, T1487, S0364)
Malicious macros (T1204)
Weaponized Excel and Word documents (T1204, T1221, T1173)
Script based backdoors (T1064, T1027)
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
Webshell deployment (T1108, T1133, T1190, T1027)
Domain masquerading (T1328)
Scheduled tasks (T1053)
Use of Mimikatz (T1003, T1207, T1098, T1081, S0002)
Exploitation of enterprise VPN Software (T1133, T1210)

General Mitigations: With this knowledge of common behaviors, some mitigations recommendations are:

Increase education and awareness against phishing attacks in your organization via exercises and informational resources
Enable or implement multi-factor authentication on public facing systems, or more preferably, across the entire organization
Enable or implement credential theft detection features in network security devices
Enable or implement anomalous DNS behavior detection/prevention capability
Blacklist EldoS RawDisk driver, unless absolutely required for business purposes
Review security policies for macro documents and restrict execution where possible
Review security policies for script file execution on endpoints and restrict where possible
Review all public facing network applications and deploy up-to-date patches
Enable or implement domain or URL categorization features in network security devices
Scan endpoints for new or unknown scheduled tasks
Implement detection and prevention logic for behaviors associated with Mimikatz
Patch remotely exposed software for known vulnerabilities as soon as possible

Palo Alto Networks’ Customer Mitigations: Palo Alto Networks customers should adopt best practices and evaluate their security posture to protect against the threats outlined in this document as well as other threats that may impact their network and users.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
Best Practice Resources
Best Practice Assessment
Security Lifecycle Review

Group Details
OilRig (AKA APT34/Helix Kitten)
https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049/
OilRig is a threat group Unit 42 named and discovered in May 2016.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Since then, we have extensively researched their campaigns and operations.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: This threat group is extremely persistent and relies heavily on spear-phishing as their initial attack vector, but has also been associated with other more sophisticated attacks such credential harvesting campaigns and DNS hijacking.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: In their spear-phishing attacks, OilRig preferred macro-enabled Microsoft Office (Word and Excel) documents to install their custom payloads that came in the form of portable executables (PE), PowerShell and VBScripts.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: OilRig’s custom payloads frequently used DNS tunneling as a command and control (C2) channel.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Once gaining access to an end point, actors would use credential dumping tools, such as Mimikatz to gather credentials to legitimate accounts to then move laterally to other systems on the network.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: When presented with a webserver, OilRig would install a webshell as another ingress point to maintain access to the network.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

Magic Hound (AKA APT35/Newscaster/Cobalt Gypsy)
https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059/
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The Magic Hound campaign targeted energy, government, and technology organizations with spear-phishing emails as a delivery mechanism.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: These emails delivered macro-enabled Microsoft Office documents and PE files within attachments.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The documents and executables attached to emails would install a variety of tools from portable PE files, .NET
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Framework PE files, Meterpreter, IRC bots, an open sourced Meterpreter module called Magic Unicorn, and an open sourced Python RAT called Pupy.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The custom tools used in the Magic Hound campaign provided connections to other threat groups, such as the IRC Bot which was very similar to the Parastoo tool associated with the NEWSCASTER threat group.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Also, a Magic Hound C2 server was also used as a C2 server for a tool called MPKBot that had been associated with the Rocket Kitten threat group.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
References
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-magic-hound-campaign-attacks-saudi-targets/
APT33 (AKA Refined Kitten/Elfin)
https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064/
APT33 is a threat group thought to have strong interest in the aeronautics and energy sectors.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: They use spear-phishing attacks with a domain masquerading technique to make the links in their emails appear legitimate.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: They are known to use custom tools in conjunction with well-known publicly available backdoors that are sold in various hacking forums.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: A recent report uncovered this threat group’s attack infrastructure, which leveraged commercial VPN providers in addition to compromised systems to use as proxies to further mask their origins.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: This activity exemplified how this adversary group and other related groups will attack organizations outside of their mission objective to augment their own capabilities to complete their task.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
References
https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2017/09/apt33-insights-into-iranian-cyber-espionage.html
https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/more-than-a-dozen-obfuscated-apt33-botnets-used-for-extreme-narrow-targeting/
DarkHydrus
https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079/
The DarkHydrus threat group has targeted government entities and educational institutions with spear-phishing attacks and credential harvesting campaigns.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: DarkHydrus is a more sophisticated group when compared to others operating in the region, as their toolset and TTPs show a higher skill level.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: DarkHydrus has used custom tools in addition to publicly available red-teaming tools such as Phishery.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: They have also been observed using Google Drive for their C2 channel.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
References
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-new-threat-actor-group-darkhydrus-targets-middle-east-government/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-darkhydrus-uses-phishery-harvest-credentials-middle-east/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/darkhydrus-delivers-new-trojan-that-can-use-google-drive-for-c2-communications/
Shamoon
The original Shamoon attack was launched in 2012 and targeted two specific organizations in the energy sector with the goal of rendering their respective computer systems inoperable by wiping their disks.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The attack package included a commercially available driver to execute the wiping tasks and also included a worming component which allowed the package to spread within a target organization in an automated manner.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: The 2012 incident was one of the first large scale targeted destructive attacks that had been publicly shared.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Since the original 2012 attack, two other instances of Shamoon have been discovered, in 2016 as well as 2018.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: In each instance, the primary capabilities and functionality remained largely the same.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
References
https://securelist.com/shamoon-the-wiper-copycats-at-work/57854/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-shamoon-2-return-disttrack-wiper/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-second-wave-shamoon-2-attacks-identified/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-shamoon-2-delivering-disttrack/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/shamoon-3-targets-oil-gas-organization/
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/shamoon-3-modified-open-source-wiper-contains-verse-from-the-quran/
MuddyWater (AKA Static Kitten)
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: MuddyWater is a group that emerged in 2017 and was initially thought to be part of the financially motivated criminal group commonly referred to as FIN7 due to the use of an open source tool that was used by both sets of activity.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Additional investigation revealed no other similarities in either tools or tactics, thus concluding that the MuddyWater activity was likely operated by a separate actor.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: This group generally used spear-phishing with macro-enabled Office documents to deliver their payloads, which were either embedded directly in the macro, or hosted on a first stage C2 server.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: These C2 servers were observed to be either third party file hosting sites or code sharing repositories such as GitHub.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
A significant portion of MuddyWater’s toolset consisted of open sourced red-teaming tools such as Invoke-Obfuscation, Lazagne, Mimikatz, etc.
References
https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-muddying-the-water-targeted-attacks-in-the-middle-east/
https://securelist.com/muddywater/88059/
https://www.clearskysec.com/muddywater2/
https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/muddywater-resurfaces-uses-multi-stage-backdoor-powerstats-v3-and-new-post-exploitation-tools/
Conclusion
Assuming the highlighted groups are indeed Iranian in origin, their activity has been well documented and the various groups often times use very similar tactics and techniques to execute their attacks, such as the heavy use of spear-phishing and credential harvesting.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: This activity has been persistent for the last decade, and it should be expected to continue or increase with recent geopolitical events.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: However, across all of these groups as well as others that were not highlighted, another consistent theme has been the abuse of poorly implemented IT and security policies.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: Enabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) throughout an organization, properly segmenting networks, limited macro-enabled documents, and disallowing network activity to unknown domains are examples of relatively simple policies that could have assisted in the neutralization of these adversary groups’ malicious actions.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text:
Indicators
Unit 42 has consolidated the IOCs of the referenced groups in this report and stored them in our GitHub repository.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

text: This dataset should not be considered comprehensive of all potential Iran-linked cyber operations, and may be subject to change without notice.
source: Threat Brief_ Iranian-Linked Cyber Operations.html

Get Free AccountJoin NowIntroduction
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Our researchers Paul Litvak and Michael Kajilolti have discovered a new campaign conducted by APT34 employing an updated toolset.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Based on uncovered phishing documents, we believe this Iranian actor is targeting Westat employees, or United States organizations hiring Westat services.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Westat is a United States-based company that “provides research services to agencies of the U.S. Government, as well as businesses, foundations, and state and local governments”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: One example of the services Westat offers is a survey for federal workers, which leads us to believe this attack may target Westat customers.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Official Westat response: “Westat understands that in their effort to identify threats and malware, Intezer has identified a malicious file that uses the Westat name and logo.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This file was not created by, hosted by, or sent from Westat, and is likely the result of a bad actor stealing the Westat brand name and logo.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Our cybersecurity team is working with Intezer and others to fully understand the nature of this report.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We will continue to monitor the situation and respond accordingly.”
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
APT34 Background
APT34 (also known as OilRig or Helix Kitten) is a cluster of Iranian government-backed cyber espionage activities that has been active since 2014.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The group is known to target various international organizations, mainly in the Middle East.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Among their targeted industries are government agencies, financial services, energy and utilities, telecommunications, and oil and gas.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: More light was shed on this group in April 2019 as leaks emerged from a mysterious individual with the pseudonym “Lab Dookhtegan”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This individual exposed data belonging to victims of this group, together with source code of hacking tools and data about previous APT34 operations; including IP addresses and domains where the group hosted web shells related to past operations.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Most recently, FireEye exposed a spear-phishing operation conducted by APT34, which enabled us to connect this operation to this Iranian actor due to similarities in the techniques and tools employed in both campaigns.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Initial Vector
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In late January 2020, we discovered a file named survey.xls that was designed to look like an employee satisfaction survey tailored to either Westat employees or Westat customers.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: At first the spreadsheet appeared to be blank.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Only once the victim enables macros, the survey is displayed to the user and the malicious VBA code begins to execute.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
survey.xls
The embedded VBA code unpacks a zip file into a temporary folder, extracts a “Client update.exe” executable file and installs it to “C:Users<User>valsClient update.exe”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: “Client update.exe” is actually a highly modified version of the TONEDEAF malware, which we named TONEDEAF 2.0.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Finally, the crtt function creates a scheduled task “CheckUpdate” that runs the unpacked executable five minutes after being infected by it, as well as on future log-ons.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Survey.xls VBA Code
Both the extracted VBA code and the functionality of the code look similar to the one analyzed in the FireEye report:
APT34 VBA Code from the FireEye Report
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In addition, we found a similar document labelled as “Employee satisfaction survey.xls” containing the same survey as the previous document.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Employee Satisfaction survey.xls
However, it’s important to highlight that the code page field of this document is Arabic as can be seen when examining its file metadata, denoting the preferred language installed on the document author’s version of Microsoft Excel:

Employee Satisfaction survey.xls Metadata
TONEDEAF 2.0
At first glance, “Client update.exe” seems like a completely new backdoor malware.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: However, further examination reveals it’s most likely a highly modified version of the previously seen TONEDEAF backdoor.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: TONEDEAF is a backdoor that communicates with its Command and Control server via HTTP in order to receive and execute commands.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It was mentioned in FireEye’s recent report about an ongoing APT34 operation, as one of the group’s custom tools.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We have named the new variant TONEDEAF 2.0.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: TONEDEAF 2.0 is an advanced version of TONEDEAF, serving the same purpose as the original, but with a revamped C2 communication protocol and a substantially modified code base.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In contrast to the original TONEDEAF, TONEDEAF 2.0 contains solely arbitrary shell execution capabilities, and doesn’t support any predefined commands.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It’s also more stealthy and contains new tricks such as dynamic importing, string decoding, and a victim deception method.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
New Tricks
Upon execution the backdoor checks whether it was executed with “…” as an argument, which is the way it’s configured to execute by the scheduled task, as part of the proper infection chain.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In the case it’s executed without the correct argument, such as by launching it via a double click, it will display a blank GUI Window to the user.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This is most likely intended to serve as a deception method, to make the malware appear like a legitimate (alibiet broken) application titled “Bee”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
GUI Window Used for Deception
TONEDEAF 2.0 also attempts to be more stealthy than its predecessor by hiding many of the interesting API imports it uses.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The names of these APIs, and the DLLs that contain them, are stored as encoded strings and are decoded and resolved on demand during runtime.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Decoding and Resolving API Functions
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: C2 Communication
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The backdoor uses HTTP for C2 communication, with a custom encoding and handshake mechanisms.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Messages sent by the backdoor always contain the HTTP query parameter “?ser=<6 digits>” as an identifier.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The first three digits are the <server_id> and the last three are the <client_id>.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
The backdoor will use one of the following two messages:
1.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: GET /dow?ser=<server_id><client_id>  – request message, used to obtain commands to execute from the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html
Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: POST /upl?ser==<server_id><client_id>  – reply to command message, used to send the executed command’s output to the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Before performing the first request, the malware will generate the <client_id> derived from the environment variables %HOMEPATH% and %COMPUTERNAME% using a custom formula.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It will then send an initial GET message to the C2 using that ID.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
C2 Request
One odd element about the communication is the usage of a Windows Phone User-Agent  value in the HTTP message.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: During our analysis the C2 was alive but continuously replied with a 403 Forbidden HTTP error code to our requests.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It’s possible that the C2 is filtering the targets since this backdoor is part of a targeted operation and our client_id parameter does not match that of one of the intended victims.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Should the C2 accept the ID, it will reply with an encoded message that contains the <server_id> and the command the backdoor needs to execute.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The malware extracts the command by looking for an HTTP div element in the response with a special class name.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Parsing of C2 Response
The malware will then execute the command by prepending it with “cmd U c” and will send the output of the command back to the C2 using the POST reply message (2).
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
When entering the C2 via a browser, the site tries to imitate https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/, although it fails to display it properly due to a misconfiguration with the CSS, as can be seen in the console:
manygoodnews[.]com C2 webpage
We have also observed that an SSL certificate has been recently generated that matches the domain of the C2.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
SSL Certificate for the C2 Domain that was Issued One Month Ago
These findings might indicate that the attackers are in the process of transitioning into HTTPS for C2 communication, in an attempt to improve their OPSEC capabilities and avoid detection.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Traces from the Original TONEDEAF
With all of the changes and new additions, there are still enough similarities that link TONEDEAF 2.0 to the original.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: While the code is mostly modified, the general flow and functionality are similar.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The C2 communication is different but still has similarities to its predecessor, such as the usage of three digit identifiers for both the victim and the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: However, most notably there are several places in the code where the similarity is most clear.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: One such place is a function that exists in both variants, which oddly enough creates a notification icon in the Windows status bar.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The only notable changes are the usage of dynamic API resolution and the shortening of the notification message from “Updating” to “up”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Specific Function Comparison
Another instance is the code that sets the working directory of the program.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
It appears in different stages for each variant, but is identical:
Similar Code Snippets
VALUEVAULT 2.0
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We were unable to download further modules, however, we believe this operation also includes the usage of a VALUEVAULT implant.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: VALUEVAULT is a browser credential theft tool built in Golang, discovered by FireEye in the aforementioned APT34 operation analysis.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We found the survey.xls file uploaded to VirusTotal with a VALUEVAULT instance and a TONEDEAF 2.0 instance, uploaded from Lebanon by the same user, only a few minutes apart.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This may indicate that these malware were delivered together as part of the same attack.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This VALUEVAULT takes a more minimalistic approach than its predecessor.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Many functionalities and strings were stripped from the new binary in order to lower its noise.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Only Chrome password dumping is now supported, although interestingly the use of the file “fsociety.dat” as a password data store under the “AppData\Roaming” directory stayed the same.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
VALUEVAULT 2.0 Compilation Paths

VALUEVAULT 1.0 Compilation Paths
Furthermore, VALUEVAULT 2.0 is a 64-bit binary as opposed to VALUEVAULT 1.0 which is a 32-bit binary.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: These relatively minor changes were enough to create a fully undetected implant.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Conclusion
The last APT34 operation was exposed only a few months ago by FireEye, and judging by our current findings we can confidently state that the group has since evolved its operations.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The technical analysis of the new malware variants reveals this Iranian government-backed group has invested substantial efforts into upgrading its toolset in an attempt to evade future detection.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The binary code from these new malware samples are now indexed in our Genetic Malware Analysis platform, Intezer Analyze.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We encourage you to use our free community edition to detect and classify threats that share code with APT34 malware.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html
