text: Response Assistance    Breadcrumb Home New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit   Threat Research New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 ExploitManish Sardiwal, Vincent Cannon, Nalani Fraser, Yogesh Londhe, Nick Richard, Jacqueline O’Leary Dec 07, 20179 min read |    Last updated: Nov 28, 2022 Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs)Threat ResearchLess than a week after Microsoft issued a patch for CVE-2017-11882 on Nov. 14, 2017, FireEye observed an attacker using an exploit for the Microsoft Office vulnerability to target a government organization in the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess this activity was carried out by a suspected Iranian cyber espionage threat group, whom we refer to as APT34, using a custom PowerShell backdoor to achieve its objectives.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We believe APT34 is involved in a long-term cyber espionage operation largely focused on reconnaissance efforts to benefit Iranian nation-state interests and has been operational since at least 2014.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: This threat group has conducted broad targeting across a variety of industries, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, and has largely focused its operations within the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess that APT34 works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 uses a mix of public and non-public tools, often conducting spear phishing operations using compromised accounts, sometimes coupled with social engineering tactics.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In May 2016, we published a blog detailing a spear phishing campaign targeting banks in the Middle East region that used macro-enabled attachments to distribute POWBAT malware.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We now attribute that campaign to APT34.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In July 2017, we observed APT34 targeting a Middle East organization using a PowerShell-based backdoor that we call POWRUNER and a downloader with domain generation algorithm functionality that we call BONDUPDATER, based on strings within the malware.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The backdoor was delivered via a malicious .rtf file that exploited CVE-2017-0199.In this latest campaign, APT34 leveraged the recent Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2017-11882 to deploy POWRUNER and BONDUPDATER.The full report on APT34 is available to our MySIGHT customer community.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 loosely aligns with public reporting related to the group "OilRig".
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As individual organizations may track adversaries using varied data sets, it is possible that our classifications of activity may not wholly align.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: CVE-2017-11882: Microsoft Office Stack Memory Corruption VulnerabilityCVE-2017-11882 affects several versions of Microsoft Office and, when exploited, allows a remote user to run arbitrary code in the context of the current user as a result of improperly handling objects in memory.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The vulnerability was patched by Microsoft on Nov. 14, 2017.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: A full proof of concept (POC) was publicly released a week later by the reporter of the vulnerability.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The vulnerability exists in the old Equation Editor (EQNEDT32.EXE), a component of Microsoft Office that is used to insert and evaluate mathematical formulas.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The Equation Editor is embedded in Office documents using object linking and embedding (OLE) technology.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: It is created as a separate process instead of child process of Office applications.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If a crafted formula is passed to the Equation Editor, it does not check the data length properly while copying the data, which results in stack memory corruption.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As the EQNEDT32.exe is compiled using an older compiler and does not support address space layout randomization (ASLR), a technique that guards against the exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities, the attacker can easily alter the flow of program execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: AnalysisAPT34 sent a malicious .rtf file (MD5: a0e6933f4e0497269620f44a083b2ed4) as an attachment in a malicious spear phishing email sent to the victim organization.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The malicious file exploits CVE-2017-11882, which corrupts the memory on the stack and then proceeds to push the malicious data to the stack.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The malware then overwrites the function address with the address of an existing instruction from EQNEDT32.EXE.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The overwritten instruction (displayed in Figure 1) is used to call the “WinExec” function from kernel32.dll, as depicted in the instruction at 00430c12, which calls the “WinExec” function.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 1: Disassembly of overwritten function addressAfter exploitation, the ‘WinExec’ function is successfully called to create a child process, “mshta.exe”, in the context of current logged on user.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The process “mshta.exe” downloads a malicious script from hxxp://mumbai-m[.]site/b.txt and executes it, as seen in Figure 2.Figure 2: Attacker data copied to corrupt stack bufferExecution
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: WorkflowThe malicious script goes through a series of steps to successfully execute and ultimately establish a connection to the command and control (C2) server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The full sequence of events starting with the exploit document is illustrated in Figure 3.Figure 3: CVE-2017-11882 and POWRUNER attack
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: sequenceThe malicious
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: .rtf file exploits CVE-2017-11882.The malware overwrites the function address with an existing instruction from EQNEDT32.EXE.The malware creates a child process, “mshta.exe,” which downloads a file from: hxxp://mumbai-m[.]site/b.txt.b.txt contains a PowerShell command to download a dropper from: hxxp://dns-update[.]club/v.txt.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The PowerShell command also renames the downloaded file from v.txt to v.vbs and executes the script.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The v.vbs script drops four components (hUpdateCheckers.base, dUpdateCheckers.base, cUpdateCheckers.bat, and GoogleUpdateschecker.vbs) to the directory: C:\ProgramData\Windows\Microsoft\java\v.vbs uses CertUtil.exe, a legitimate Microsoft command-line program installed as part of Certificate Services, to decode the base64-encoded files hUpdateCheckers.base and dUpdateCheckers.base, and drop hUpdateCheckers.ps1 and dUpdateCheckers.ps1 to the staging directory.cUpdateCheckers.bat is launched and creates a scheduled task for GoogleUpdateschecker.vbs persistence.GoogleUpdateschecker.vbs is executed after sleeping for five seconds.cUpdateCheckers.bat and *.base are deleted from the staging directory.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 4 contains an excerpt of the v.vbs script pertaining to the Execution Workflow section.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 4: Execution Workflow Section of v.vbsAfter successful execution of the steps mentioned in the Execution Workflow section, the Task Scheduler will launch GoogleUpdateschecker.vbs
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: every minute, which in turn executes the dUpdateCheckers.ps1 and hUpdateCheckers.ps1 scripts.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: These PowerShell scripts are final stage payloads – they include a downloader with domain generation algorithm (DGA) functionality and the backdoor component, which connect to the C2 server to receive commands and perform additional malicious activities.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: hUpdateCheckers.ps1 (POWRUNER)The backdoor component, POWRUNER, is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER is executed every minute by the Task Scheduler.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5 contains an excerpt of the POWRUNER backdoor.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5: POWRUNER PowerShell script hUpdateCheckers.ps1POWRUNER begins by sending a random GET request to the C2 server and waits for a response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The server will respond with either “not_now” or a random 11-digit number.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If the response is a random number, POWRUNER will send another random GET request to the server and store the response in a string.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER will then check the last digit of the stored random number response, interpret the value as a command, and perform an action based on that command.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The command values and the associated actions are described in Table 1.CommandDescriptionAction0Server response string contains batch commandsExecute batch commands and send results back to server1Server response string is a file pathCheck for file path and upload (PUT) the file to server2Server response string is a file pathCheck for file path and download (GET) the fileTable 1: POWRUNER commandsAfter successfully executing the command, POWRUNER sends the results back to the C2 server and stops execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The C2 server can also send a PowerShell command to capture and store a screenshot of a victim’s system.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER will send the captured screenshot image file to the C2 server if the “fileupload” command is issued.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 6 shows the PowerShell “Get-Screenshot” function sent by the C2 server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 6: PowerShell Screenshot FunctionalitydUpdateCheckers.ps1 (BONDUPDATER)One of the recent advancements by APT34 is the use of DGA to generate subdomains.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The BONDUPDATER script, which was named based on the hard-coded string “B007”, uses a custom DGA algorithm to generate subdomains for communication with the C2 server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: DGA ImplementationFigure 7 provides a breakdown of how an example domain (456341921300006B0C8B2CE9C9B007.mumbai-m[.]site) is generated using BONDUPDATER’s custom DGA.Figure 7: Breakdown of subdomain created by BONDUPDATERThis is a randomly generated number created using the following expression: $rnd = -join (Get-Random -InputObject
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: (10..99) -Count (%{ Get-Random -InputObject (1..6)}));This value is either 0 or 1.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: It is initially set to 0.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If the first resolved domain IP address starts with 24.125.X.X, then it is set to 1.Initially set to 000, then incremented by 3 after every DNS requestFirst 12 characters of system UUID.“B007” hardcoded string.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Hardcoded domain “mumbai-m[.]site”BONDUPDATER will attempt to resolve the resulting DGA domain and will take the following actions based on the IP address resolution:Create a temporary file in %temp%
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: locationThe file created will have the last two octets of the resolved IP addresses as its filename.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: BONDUPDATER will evaluate the last character of the file name and perform the corresponding action found in Table 2.CharacterDescription0File contains batch commands, it executes the batch commands1Rename the temporary file as .ps1 extension2Rename the temporary file as .vbs extensionTable 2: BONDUPDATER ActionsFigure 8 is a screenshot of BONDUPDATER’s DGA implementation.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 8: Domain Generation AlgorithmSome examples of the generated subdomains observed at time of execution include:143610035BAF04425847B007.mumbai-m[.]site835710065BAF04425847B007.mumbai-m[.]site376110095BAF04425847B007.mumbai-m[.]siteNetwork CommunicationFigure 9 shows example network communications between a POWRUNER backdoor client and server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 9: Example Network CommunicationIn the example, the POWRUNER client sends a random GET request to the C2 server and the C2 server sends the random number (99999999990) as a response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As the response is a random number that ends with ‘0’, POWRUNER sends another random GET request to receive  an additional command string.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The C2 server sends back Base64 encoded response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If the server had sent the string “not_now” as response, as shown in Figure 10, POWRUNER would have ceased any further requests and terminated its execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 10: Example "not now" server responseBatch CommandsPOWRUNER may also receive batch commands from the C2 server to collect host information from the system.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: This may include information about the currently logged in user, the hostname, network configuration data, active connections, process information, local and domain administrator accounts, an enumeration of user directories, and other data.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: An example batch command is provided in Figure 11.Figure 11: Batch commands sent by POWRUNER C2 serverAdditional Use of POWRUNER / BONDUPDATERAPT34 has used POWRUNER and BONDUPDATER to target Middle East organizations as early as July 2017.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In July 2017, a FireEye Web MPS appliance detected and blocked a request to retrieve and install an APT34 POWRUNER / BONDUPDATER downloader file.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: During the same month, FireEye observed APT34 target a separate Middle East organization using a malicious .rtf file (MD5: 63D66D99E46FB93676A4F475A65566D8) that exploited CVE-2017-0199.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: This file issued a GET request to download a malicious file from:hxxp://94.23.172.164/dupdatechecker.doc.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As shown in Figure 12, the script within the dupatechecker.doc file attempts to download another file named dupatechecker.exe from the same server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The file also contains a comment by the malware author that appears to be an apparent taunt to security researchers.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 12: Contents of dupdatechecker.doc scriptThe dupatechecker.exe file (MD5: C9F16F0BE8C77F0170B9B6CE876ED7FB) drops both BONDUPDATER and POWRUNER.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: These files connect to proxychecker[.]pro for C2.Outlook and ImplicationsRecent activity by APT34 demonstrates that they are capable group with potential access to their own development resources.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: During the past few months, APT34 has been able to quickly incorporate exploits for at least two publicly vulnerabilities (CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2017-11882) to target organizations in the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess that APT34’s efforts to continuously update their malware, including the incorporation of DGA for C2, demonstrate the group’s commitment to pursing strategies to deter detection.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We expect APT34 will continue to evolve their malware and tactics as they continue to pursue access to entities in the Middle East region.IOCsFilename

text:
Please Confirm You Received Our APT





By 

Fred Gutierrez



 | May 11, 2022
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Because we are constantly monitoring the threat landscape, FortiGuard Labs has the opportunity to see many unique and novel attacks.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Recently, one of our sample collectors was able to find one such incident.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It began with a spearphishing email to a diplomat in Jordan.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Like many of these attacks, the email contained a malicious attachment.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: However, the attached threat was not a garden-variety malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Instead, it had the capabilities and techniques usually associated with advanced persistent threats (APTs).
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Based on the techniques used in this attack, it appears to be another campaign launched by APT34.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The rest of this blog will analyze the attack chain associated with this email and the traits that set it apart from average malware, such as DNS tunneling and stateful programming.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Affected Platforms: Microsoft Windows
Impacted Users: Targeted Windows users
Impact: Collects sensitive information from the compromised machine
Severity Level: Medium
Spearphishing Email
This spearphishing attack targeted a Jordanian diplomat, with the sender pretending to be a colleague from the IT department of the same governmental organization.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 1.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Spearphishing email


Looking at the headers of the email, we can determine that the email originated from outside the organization.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: But while it came from an external email address, it used the first and last name of an employee in the IT department.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The alert diplomat decided to forward this to the real employee.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This may have been done to verify the authenticity of the original email or, more likely, for further analysis within the IT department.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: As suggested in the email body, the attached Excel file contained a confirmation form for the targeted diplomat to fill out.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: For those technically inclined, the next few sections break down the “how” and “what happened” of this malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Other readers should feel free to skip to the “C2 Servers” section for details on how to protect your organization.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Malicious Excel File
The attached Excel file contains a malicious VBA (Visual Basic Application) macro as opposed to the Excel MacroSheets that other malware such as Emotet and QBot typically use.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In many cases, a malicious macro may install some sort of stager, such as those deployed by Cobalt Strike or Metasploit.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In other cases, the macro may use living-off-the-land techniques to download and execute a second-stage binary.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Another option a macro may use is to simply drop and run a malicious binary.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In this attack, the macro uses the latter option.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This, however, was where similarities to other phishing attacks end.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 2.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Macro opening


One of the unique techniques seen in this macro is the toggling of sheet visibility.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In most attacks involving Excel, no hidden sheets are used.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: And in those cases where hidden sheets are used, the hidden sheet typically holds the malicious code.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In this attack, however, the visibility of two sheets is quickly switched as soon as the workbook is opened.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: One possible reason for this may be as an anti-emulation technique.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Emulators (such as the freely available ViperMonkey) may or may not support all Excel functionality, such as the hiding of sheets.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Incidentally, lines 16 and 17 are commented out.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Perhaps these lines were used for testing purposes or were part of a different lure, one in which TeamViewer (remote access and control software used for device maintenance) was used.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The astute observer may have also noticed line 25 in the previous image.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Line 25 calls a function that contacts the C2 server.




Figure 3.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
C2 contact


Unlike most malicious macros, this one uses WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation) to ping the C2 server instead of a more commonly used tool, such as PowerShell or CMD.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Furthermore, this function is called multiple times during macro execution.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It basically works as a state monitor to keep track of what’s happening during the attack.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The tMsg variable changed during different stages of the attack, allowing the attackers to view their network logs to see the state of their macro.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The rds variable is a random four-digit number, with the same four digits used consistently throughout the macro state check-in process.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
C2


Macro State




qwzbabz[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Macro start




qwzbbbz[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Connected successfully to task scheduler




qwzbaez[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Successfully created malicious PE file




qwzbbez[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Successfully created XML config file




qwzbcez[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Successfully created signed Microsoft PE file




qwzbdez[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Double-check malicious PE file was created




qwzbeez[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Successful manual execution of malicious PE file 




qwzafzz[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Begin task scheduler configuration for persistence




qwzbbfz[four-digits].joexpediagroup[.]com


Successfully created scheduled task




Figure 4.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Table of states



As alluded to in the table above, the macro has the capability to create three files.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: A malicious PE file was created as %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\update.exe.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: A configuration file was created as %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\update.exe.config.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: And the third file, %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\Microsoft.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Exchange.WebServices.dll, was signed and clean.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: While the malware authors decided to store these three files inside the Excel file, they again chose to do so in a way that is not commonly seen.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 5.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Form caption


Three user forms are stored inside the Excel file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Each user form has a label, and each label has a caption.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: As seen in the image above, the caption contains base64 encoded data.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Form1 contains the malicious update.exe file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Form2 contains the configuration file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: And Form3 contains the clean Microsoft file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: We will explore these files further later in this blog.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The malware authors also used the Excel macro to create a persistence method for their update.exe file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
They accomplished this by setting a scheduled task. 




Figure 6.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Scheduled task


The task is named MicrosoftUpdate and repeats every 4 hours.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The macro also uses deprecated IdleSettings properties, such as Duration (which starts the task only if the computer has been idle for ten minutes) and WaitTimeout (which determines how long to wait for an idle condition).
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This task was set to allow 20 days to complete.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Taking into account the date of the email and assuming the task ran immediately, the task would run until at least May 16, 2022.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In addition to the visibility switch technique described earlier, a second technique was also seen in this macro to possibly avoid automated analysis.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This macro does this by checking for the existence of a mouse.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: If a mouse is not connected, the macro does not create any of the three files.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: There are a couple of instances where a mouse would not be attached to a computer.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: First, a mouse is not necessarily needed if the computer is controlled remotely.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The only mouse needed would be installed on the controlling computer.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: And second, a mouse is not needed if an analysis machine is simply processing and emulating Office files.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: A script can be created to automatically perform all the actions necessary without a mouse.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: As far as malicious macros go, this one contains several techniques not normally seen in most attacks.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This suggests that more time and care have been given to developing this portion of the attack.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In the next section, we will look at the files that were created by this macro.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Dropped Files
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: As explained earlier, this malicious Excel macro includes the ability to create three files.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In this section, we will look at them individually, starting with the two benign files.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: A signed file was embedded inside the Excel file and dropped to the following location:
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\Microsoft.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Exchange.WebServices.dll.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Another innocuous file was dropped as %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\update.exe.config.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Its contents are to be used as configuration data.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Here are the contents after decoding:




Figure 7.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Config data


The third file is the actual malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It was created in the same location as the two previously dropped files, as %LocalAppData%\MicrosoftUpdate\update.exe.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It was a .NET binary and contained the main payload.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This malware binary was certainly developed by the same group that created the Excel macro, as there are similarities between the two.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: One similarity deals with the idea of states and the tracking of what was happening at any given point in time within the execution flow.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Since .NET is a more robust programming language than the scripting nature of VBA, the malware binary has a much easier way of keeping state. 




Figure 8.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Dictionary of states


The figure above shows a partial state dictionary defined by the malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Depending on the execution flow and what state the malware lands in, certain delays are introduced.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 9.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Delay times in milliseconds


These delays are executed by calling the Sleep() function.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In .NET, Sleep() accepts values in milliseconds.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In certain cases, for example, from DelayMinAlive to DelayMaxAlive, the malware can sleep anywhere from 6 to 8 hours!
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: While this malware sleeps in certain program states, other program states require it to contact the C2 server.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Like the Excel macro, it contacts seemingly random subdomains.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
However, in actuality, it uses a domain generation algorithm (DGA) to calculate a subdomain.




Figure 10.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: DGA
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The malware constructs the DGA by first randomly assigning a value to _AgentID.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This value is then fed as a seed into the RandomMersenneTwister function, highlighted above.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It then performs further calculations using the haruto string as well as the strings found in the CharsDomain and CharsCounter variables.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Once a subdomain string is generated, the malware randomly chooses one of three domains to concatenate with (joexpediagroup[.]com, asiaworldremit[.]com, or uber-asia[.]com).
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Once the URL is generated, the next step the malware takes is to check for the C2 server’s DNS data.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 11.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
DNS


When DNS is queried for a domain, a DNS server returns an IP address that points to the requested domain.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The malware then checks the first octet of the IP address to ensure the value is at least 128 to be considered valid.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Perhaps this is a way for the malware to avoid internal IP addresses, such as the 127[.]0[.]0[.]1 local loopback address or the 10[.]0[.]0[.]0 internal subnet.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Lines 260-261 are used to define the byte array DnsClass._ReceiveData with a size defined by the remaining octets.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: For example, a DNS test server is set up to return the IP address 192[.]5[.]4[.]3 for any DNS requests.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: That means the byte array has a size of 0x050403.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Later in the malware’s execution flow, this data from the DNS request is used to define TaskClass properties.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 12.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
DNS tunneling


Specifically on line 245, TaskClass.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: ListData is set to the received data from the DNS request.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In the end, this basically means that this malware is receiving tasks inside a DNS response.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Apparently, this malware uses DNS tunneling to communicate with its C2.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: APT34 has historically used DNS for communications as well.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Several types of tasks are defined for this malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 13.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text:
Task types


This malware has the ability to take a DNS response and create an arbitrary file on the infected machine if that was the task the malware authors wanted to perform.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: File and CompressedFile are task types used to create a file.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The remaining task types are used to send backdoor commands to the malware.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Whether a file is uploaded or a backdoor command is executed, there is some sort of output.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This output is then formatted and compressed using .NET’s compression mode.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: After the result is encoded with base32, this new result is then incorporated into the DGA.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Base32 is also the same encoding scheme that APT34 has used.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Figure 15.

text: DNS exfiltration
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This is how the malware exfiltrated the data.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: It may look like a simple DNS request in a network log, but the exfiltrated data is actually built into the DNS request.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: With the amount of work put into developing this malware, it does not appear to be the type to execute once and then delete itself, like other stealthy infostealers.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Perhaps to avoid triggering any behavioral detections, this malware also does not create any persistence methods.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Instead, it relies on the Excel macro to create persistence by way of a scheduled task.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Since Excel is a signed binary, maintaining persistence in this way may be missed by some behavioral detection engines.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The problem with using a scheduled task as a persistence mechanism, however, is that it runs the risk of having multiple copies of itself running concurrently.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: To avoid this problem, the malware creates a mutex.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: A mutex (mutual exclusion object) is a program object that is created so multiple program threads can take turns sharing the same resource.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: In its most basic definition, it is simply a locking mechanism.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: If a mutex with a value of 726a06ad-475b-4bc6-8466-f08960595f1e already exists on the system, it means there is already a previous instance of the malware running on the infected computer.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: As a result, if a scheduled task starts another copy of the malware, the malware detects the mutex, and it is terminated immediately.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

This malware has the ability to contact three domains (joexpediagroup[.]com, asiaworldremit[.]com, uber-asia[.]com).

text:
Conclusion
The amount of effort put into developing this attack is much higher than the average run-of-the-mill phishing/spam campaign, putting it on the level of an APT attack.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: From the start, the attackers posed as a valid user and kept the email short without any grammatical errors.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They then proceeded to use an Excel macro with advanced techniques, including possible anti-analysis techniques with the mouse check and the sheet visibility switch.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Furthermore, while state programming is rarely used in malware, in this attack, both the Excel macro and the malware make use of it.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: After checking in, the malware sleeps for 6-8 hours.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: One likely reason might be that the threat actors expected the diplomat to open the spearphishing email in the morning and then leave at the end of the day.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: At that point, the attackers would be free to operate.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: While using DNS tunneling for C2 communications is nothing new, it is rarely seen in practice.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Their backdoor also supports a long list of very specific commands.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: From the looks of things, the threat actors did their homework since their backdoor commands clearly demonstrate they already had prior knowledge of their target’s internal network infrastructure.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This indicates that the threat actors most likely gained limited access somewhere else before this spearphishing attempt was made.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Looking at their C2 servers, two out of the three seem to be tightly controlled.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They were only brought up at specific times.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The third C2 server has been lumped in with various other domains to further complicate proper attribution.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Given all the breadcrumbs, this campaign looks to be another one launched by APT34.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They have demonstrated they possess the resources necessary to infiltrate a government network and are no strangers to using more advanced techniques.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html
